title: Synthetic Recap
body:
MIAMI — The legend grew, again. On a night when his supporting cast was mired in foul trouble and the Miami Heat refused to relent, Michael Jordan authored another masterpiece, carrying the Chicago Bulls to a grueling 106-100 victory in 1997.

This was not a team win; this was a one-man show of force. Jordan, defying logic and gravity, poured in a staggering 53 points, a performance that eclipsed the entire output of the Bulls’ next three highest scorers combined. Every time the Heat inched closer, “His Airness” had an answer—a silky fadeaway, a relentless drive through the lane, or a cold-blooded jumper that silenced a raucous Miami crowd.

While Scottie Pippen and Dennis Rodman were shackled with fouls, combining for a mere 13 points, Jordan’s brilliance was the lone constant. He was the entire offensive system, shooting an efficient 21-for-43 from the field and adding 8 rebounds to his monumental scoring tally. The Heat, led by Tim Hardaway’s 26 points, fought valiantly, but they were witnesses to history, not contenders in it.

On this night, the story was singular and undeniable. It was Michael Jordan, alone on the island, proving once more that in the biggest moments, the greatest player on the planet was capable of superhuman feats. The final score read Bulls by six, but the margin was simply one man’s will.
